Tom and Arnold, thanks for your replies, you both made excellent
observatio=
ns.

I spoke with Robert Haynes yesterday and raised the issue with him. 

=
To summarize, he was not aware of any particular problem with gimei pieces,=

in fact he said that compared to other references (like Wakayama) that wer=
e
produced from submitted photographic examples (which Arnold pointed out,)=

Kinko Meikan was done mostly from examples in hand and was a more reliable=

reference.

He of course mentioned, as Tom pointed out, there is not reall=
y a problem
using the translation with the later edition if one is willing =
to work a
little at reading the kanji and kana, and certainly one will lear=
n more by
doing so.

Bob said that he had started to make a comparison list=
 between the first and
later editions, as some examples in the first were d=
ropped, most stayed, and
of course many were added. His conclusion has been=
 that the later edition is
more complete and accurate and therefore the bet=
ter reference.

Of course that still leaves me wondering *which* book it wa=
s that supposedly
had many gimei in the first edition ... or if my memory i=
s manufacturing
things.

Craig Harris
